newsitem.title: GERMANY: German tax reform might be gradually phased in.
newsitem.headline: German tax reform might be gradually phased in.

text.p: Parts of a major reform of Germany's tax system scheduled for 1999 may have to be introduced after the planned start date, leading German coalition government figures said on Sunday.
Michael Glos, parliamentary leader of finance minister Theo Waigel's Christian Social Union, said the core points of a plan for huge income tax cuts would be implemented by 1999.
"But one or other (of the reforms) might not be quite so easily financed as we imagine," he told German radio, adding that any remaining parts of the plan would be put into effect in 2000 and 2001.
Waigel himself had told journalists on the borders of the European Union summit in Dublin on Saturday that a phased-in approach was "conceivable".
Neither Waigel or Glos said which parts of the reform might have to wait until after 1999.
Chancellor Helmut Kohl's three-party alliance wants to make income tax cuts to boost Germany's economy in a move which could result in some 100 billion marks of lost revenue.
Tighter controls on tax evasion are expected to offset some of the loss coming from the reform, the full proposals of which are due to be announced early next year.
Waigel favours cutting the entry income tax rate to around 20 percent from 26 percent and reducing the top tax bracket from 53 percent to 40 percent.
Kohl's CDU party wants value added tax to rise by two percentage points, a move which has met with strong opposition.

Rudolf Scharping, parliamentary leader for the opposition Social Democrats (SPD), said in a newspaper interview his party would oppose any increase in value added tax, which is often seen as hitting poorer people hardest.
"We need tax reductions for the wide majority contributors in Germany," he told the Bild am Sonntag newspaper.
SPD party leader Oskar Fontaine told German radio on Sunday that a tax reform that reduced the burden on low-earners was not only fair but "made economic sense".
